div1.p: Carter describes the literature he is covering for his abstracts.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Bruce Mayne, January 21, 1922
div1.p: In answer to your letter just received, I would say

1/ That I am not attempting to cover all the literature--just
such journal and reports, in languages that I can read, as come to
the Bureau and such as references in these lead me to look up in
other libraries. I could take up all that come to our own or the
Library of the Surgeon General of the Army in English: French or Span-
ish--Dutch articles are also published in English translation--and
may do so later.

2/ It is original articles that I am working with, the titles
given at the head of the abstract show where they come from.

There is practically nothing directly touching the engineering
work for malaria control, but I hope they get something out of the
biology of Anopheles. I have tried to tie the foreign opservations up
with American conditions and observations as much as I could. It may
interest you to know that the British found the control of malaria at
Dar-es-salaam--where Olgig had instituted sterilization of human car-
riers--a failure, and have done this by control of Anopheles production--
ditching, filling etc. They used the same device--floating timber--in
oiling large ponds that Griffitts and myself introduced at Newport News
and Pig Point earlier.

I purpose, I am sorry to say, to stop the abstracts--temporarily
2
temporarily
at least--for some other work that is pressing me.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, Assistant Surgeon General. (On Waiting Orders)
I have written another pretty are
abstract of Ranbaud's the Gendre's “Animal Protection”- w'h sh'd be out Monday
Jan 23/. This is simply an abstract. If I get time will write an ar-
ticle on it for the P. H. R.
Address
Assistant Surgeon General H. R. Carter,
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
